Oracle has confirmed that the two original Business intelligence part numbers included in the 2015 ordering document along with all its functionality for each have been consolidated into their respective base product. So original part number B69731 is now included as part of B69730, and B69716 is now part of B75289.  Below is Oracle?s current offer. deal_metadata.current_narrative: 1.0...  Thanks for sending this over for NPI to review.  This is a below the minimum dollar threshold for deals that NPI will typically review for Intuit (threshold is $100K).  However, I have a bit of Preemptive data and I did a quick analysis of this quote.  First, any type of unlimited license is very difficult to benchmark without expected usage rates.  Based on the comparative data that NPI has, $9K for an unlimited license appears to be within Fair Market Value (FMV); however, the true FMV for this will depend on how many users actually use the system.  The 12 Dotfuscator build licenses are pro-rated for 12-month (and longer) terms.  By NPI?s math, each build license has an annual cost of around $1.2K, and they are prorated out for the extended term.  Overall, this is within FMV.  NPI has seen Dotfuscator licenses offered slightly lower on larger deals, but we would consider this to be FMV.  Overall, for a deal of this size, NPI considers this pricing to be within FMV and Intuit can move forward.
deal_metadata.description: Can you please check the attached proposal for benchmarking analysis? There will be additional 8 licenses and possibly a site license.

deal_metadata.current_narrative: Infor is the preferred vendor in part because they were involved with Zumiez POS (trying to protect that information). While license costs for Infor and Kronos are comparable, the implementation from Infor's partner Axsium is more than 5x WFCs for the Kronos solution.  Other scoped implementations have fallen in a middle range of the extremes.  5/16 Received the final Subscription.  We will bill for that and wait on services.  They are looking at other PS firms to validate Axsium scope before committing.   Gregg asked KT about discounts and this is the reply that was worth capturing: We weren?t able to determine the discount, but we also haven?t received final docs or any formal Infor quote yet.  While it?s not a discount, we did see them drop pricing from $307k per year to an anticipated $265k (still waiting on the exact final number for the subscription portion, but this was communicated verbally to Zumiez as the projected price).  That?d imply an additional discount of 14%.    The implementer also discounted labor rates from $175 -> $155, an 11% drop.  Not exactly discounts but that?s what we have so far.
deal_metadata.customer_comments: The wide gap in implementation costs could mean Infor knows they are preferred and are trying to inflate costs.  Despite this, Zumiez is happy with most of Axsium's work so far.  Protecting information around Infor as the definite choice will be crucial in preserving leverage.
deal_metadata.description: Zumiez has engaged NPI on a review of their open bid around a new WFM solution.  After an open RFP, Zumiez down selected to Infor & Kronos (included Tanda very briefly after NPI involvement).  Each vendor also has a partner SI with implementation costs, Axsium for Infor and WFC for Kronos.

B67272 is the SKU that absorbed B67270.  These had respective list prices of $40 and $5 per month in 2015 and now that they?re combined the new list is still $40 for 67272.  Equifax got a 38% discount in 2015 and the current offer that we reviewed was at 52%.  The volume went up considerably from 300 to 1950 and the term lengthened from 3 years to 5 years. ?	There were two other products that comprised only 10% of the quote and had the same 52% discount and 61% target.  The renewal summarizes as follows: ?	$1.2M in list costs over five years or $240K a year ?	$674,655 in net costs over five years or ~$135K a year ?	B75289 used to list for $400.  It now includes B69716 which listed for $50.  Together they increased the new B75289 to a sizable $650/mo which is 44% more than the combined $400+$50.  NPI hasn?t done a comparison of the capabilities of the software before and after but we certainly hope Oracle can articulate the reason behind the sizable increase. o	Offered at $346.77 per month that?s a 46.7% discount.  This is less than the 52% offer on the other part of this renewal NPI recently reviewed.  In addition, compared to the combined total of the prior list prices of $450 it is a paltry 23% discount.  Of course, Oracle can highlight you only got a 25% discount in 2015 and now you?re at 46.7% (of course they raised prices 44%!) o	NPI can see that the final outcomes in 2015 of $299 and $37 total $336 for these two SKUs and the $347.77 is 3% more than this.  Numbers can really get your head spinning of course.  A 3% increase seems reasonable in the Oracle ecosphere. o	More important to NPI the fact that Equifax is signing up for 5 years not 3 and expanding your extended list subscription costs from $1,071,000 over three years to about $6.5M over five years.  That?s a HUGE increase. This is enough of a change to get this repriced vs. accepting a 3% increase.  (Caveat: NPI is assuming the review from several weeks ago is in addition to this subscription) ?	B69730 used to list for $150 and B69731 listed for $50.  You?d expect the newly-reconstituted B69730 to have increased in price but it is still at $150. o	The $103 offer is a 31% discount.  The quote 2 weeks ago had each line item the same. That is often the case with Oracle Fusion quotes but this quote has one at 46.7% and one at 31%. o	NPI can see that total net price was $100 in 2015 and $103 is a 3% increase.  These were discounted 50% in 2015.  This one dropped from 50% to 31%. A bit unusual for Oracle. o	The blended discount is 44%.   Assuming, this is in addition to the prior review NPI sees no reason to not repeat our 61% discount target across the board.  The term and list spend has increases a lot and Equifax is a huge Oracle client.  You deserve top tier pricing. This does represent a sizable $200K cost reduction which is tough to get from Oracle on a renewal that is mid quarter and can only be attained by leveraging the other renewal?s growth. Standalone a blended 44% could be considered FMV with a blended target of 50%.
